member.name: T:DotSpatial.Controls.DatelineCrossingExtentExtension
member.summary: Extension of Extent class to deal with dateline crossing.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.DatelineCrossingExtentExtension.IsCrossDateline(DotSpatial.Data.Extent)
member.summary: Indicates whether the extent crosses the date line.
member.returns: True, if the extent crosses the date line.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.DatelineCrossingExtentExtension.Normalised(DotSpatial.Data.Extent)
member.summary: Modifies the extent such that its left edge is normalised into the range [-180..180] degrees. Its width remains constant unless it was originally greater than 360 degrees, in which case it is scaled to 360 degrees width and retains its aspect ratio.

member.name: T:DotSpatial.Controls.DatelineCrossingMap
member.summary: Based on Ted's original idea in https://dotspatial.codeplex.com/discussions/232535 discussion thread, a second frame is added to complement the main frame to handle dateline crossing. First the main frame is normalized so that its left edge is in range [-180..180] and its width is bound to 360 but retains its aspect ratio. After the normalization, if main frame's right edge > 180 which indicates dateline crossing, then the main frame is clipped to 180 degrees, and the secondary frame takes over, shifted to -180 degrees to the required width.
member.remarks: Dateline crossing map works correctly only with WGS84 datum Mercator projection.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.DatelineCrossingMap.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Gets the map frame that is used to show the second part of the map.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.DatelineCrossingMap.ClipViewExtents
member.summary: Clips the view extents so each map frame shows what it is supposed to.

member.summary: This will add a new label category that will only apply to the specified filter expression. This will not remove any existing categories.
member.param: The feature layer that the labels should be applied to
The string expression where field names are in square brackets

The label symbolizer that controls the basic appearance of the labels in this category.

The string expression where field names are in square brackets
The string filter expression that controls which features are labeled. Field names are in square brackets, strings in single quotes.
The label symbolizer that controls the basic appearance of the labels in this category.
A geographic width, so that if the map is zoomed to a geographic width smaller than this value, labels should appear.

member.summary: Ensures the required imports are available for IExtension implementors. We guarantee DockManager, HeaderControl and ProgressHandler are available when an IExtension loads, so that the developer of an IExtension doesn't need to check to see whether they are null. We make sure these are available before activating an IExtension.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Controls.IBasicMap.IsBusy
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether a map-function is currently interacting with the map. If this is true, then any tool-tip like popups or other mechanisms that require lots of re-drawing should suspend themselves to prevent conflict. Setting this actually increments an internal integer, so when that integer is 0, the map is "Not" busy, but multiple busy processes can work independently.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Controls.ILegend.UseLegendForSelection
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the legend is used to determine whether a layer is selectable. If true, a layer is only selectable if it or a superior object (parental group, mapframe) is selected in legend. If false, the selectable state of the layers gets either determined by a plugin like SetSelectable or developers handle the selectable state by code. By default legend is used, but if the SetSelectable plugin gets loaded this is used instead of the legend.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.IMap.ActivateMapFunction(DotSpatial.Controls.IMapFunction)
member.summary: If the specified function is already in the list of functions, this will properly test the yield style of various map functions that are currently on and then activate the function. If this function is not in the list, then it will add it to the list. If you need to control the position, then insert the function before using this method to activate. Be warned that calling "Activate" directly on your function will activate your function but not disable any other functions. You can set "Map.FunctionMode = FunctionModes.None" first, and then specifically activate the function that you want.
member.param: The MapFunction to activate, or add.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether or not the drawing layers should cache off-screen data to the buffer. Panning will be much more elegant, but zooming, selecting and resizing will take a performance penalty.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Controls.Map.Extent
member.summary: Gets the geographic bounds of all of the different data layers currently visible on the map.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Controls.Map.FunctionMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the current tool mode. This rapidly enables or disables specific tools to give a combination of functionality. Selecting None will disable all the tools, which can be enabled manually by enabling the specific tool in the GeoTools dictionary.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Controls.Map.IsBusy
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether a map-function is currently interacting with the map. If this is true, then any tool-tip like popups or other mechanisms that require lots of re-drawing should suspend themselves to prevent conflict. Setting this actually increments an internal integer, so when that integer is 0, the map is "Not" busy, but multiple busy processess can work independantly.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the map is zoomed to its full extents. Added by Eric Hullinger 1/3/2013

member.summary: Gets or sets a PromptMode enumeration that controls how users are prompted before adding layers that have a coordinate system that is different from the map.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Controls.Map.RedrawLayersWhileResizing
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether layers should draw during the actual resize itself. The normal behavior is to draw the existing image buffer in the new size and position which is much faster for large datasets, but is not as visually appealing if you only work with small datasets.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Controls.Map.ZoomOutFartherThanMaxExtent
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether zooming out farther than the extent of the map is allowed. This is useful if we have only layers with small extents and want to look at them from farther out.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Controls.Map.DotSpatial#Controls#IBasicMap#MapFrame
member.summary: Gets the map frame.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.Map.ActivateMapFunction(DotSpatial.Controls.IMapFunction)
member.summary: If the specified function is already in the list of functions, this will properly test the yield style of various map functions that are currently on and then activate the function. If this function is not in the list, then it will add it to the list. If you need to control the position, then insert the function before using this method to activate. Be warned that calling "Activate" directly on your function will activate your function but not disable any other functions. You can set "Map.FunctionMode = FunctionModes.None" first, and then specifically activate the function that you want.
member.param: The MapFunction to activate, or add.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.Map.AddFeatureLayer
member.summary: Allows an open file dialog without multi-select enabled to add a single raster tot he map as a layer, and returns the added layer.
member.returns: The IMapFeatureLayer that was added, or null.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.Map.AddFeatureLayers
member.summary: Allows a mult-select open file dialog to specify several fileNames to add. Only files with supported vector extensions will be shown.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.Map.AddImageLayer
member.summary: Allows an open dialog without multi-select to specify a single fileName to be added to the map as a new layer and returns the newly added layer.
member.returns: The layer that was added to the map, or null.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.Map.AddImageLayers
member.summary: Allows a mult-select open file dialog to specify several fileNames to add. Only files with supported image extensions will be shown.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.Map.AddLayer(System.String)
member.summary: Adds the fileName as a new layer to the map, returning the new layer.

member.returns: The IMapLayer added to the file.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.Map.AddLayer
member.summary: Uses the file dialog to allow selection of a fileName for opening the new layer, but does not allow multiple files to be added at once.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.Map.AddLayers
member.summary: Allows the user to add a new layer to the map using an open file dialog to choose a layer file. Multi-select is an option, so this return a list with all the layers.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.Map.AddRasterLayer

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.Map.AddRasterLayers
member.summary: Allows a multi-select file dialog to add raster layers, applying a filter so that only supported raster formats will appear.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.Map.Print(System.Drawing.Graphics,System.Drawing.Rectangle)
member.summary: Instead of using the usual buffers, this bypasses any buffering and instructs the layers to draw directly to the specified target rectangle on the graphics object. This is useful for doing vector drawing on much larger pages. The result will be centered in the specified target rectangle bounds.
member.param: The graphics device to print to
the rectangle where the map content should be drawn.

This is useful for doing vector drawing on much larger pages. The result will be centered in the specified target rectangle bounds.
member.param: The graphics device to print to
the rectangle where the map content should be drawn.
the extents to print in the target rectangle

member.summary: Fires the ViewExtentsChanged event. Corrects the ViewExtent if it is smaller than 1e-7. If ZoomOutFartherThanMaxExtent is set, it corrects the ViewExtent if it is bigger then 1e+9. Otherwise it corrects the ViewExtent if it is bigger than the Maps extent + 10%.

member.summary: gets or sets the rectangle in pixel coordinates that will be drawn to the entire screen.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.IMapFrame.BufferToProj(System.Drawing.Point)
member.summary: Unlike PixelToProj, which works relative to the client control, BufferToProj takes a pixel coordinate on the buffer and converts it to geographic coordinates.
member.param: A Point describing the pixel position on the back buffer
member.returns: An ICoordinate describing the geographic position

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.IMapFrame.BufferToProj(System.Drawing.Rectangle)
member.summary: This projects a rectangle relative to the buffer into and Envelope in geographic coordinates.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.IMapFrame.Draw(System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs)
member.summary: Using the standard independent paint method would potentially cause for dis-synchrony between the parents state and the state of this control. This way, the drawing is all done at the same time.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.IMapFrame.Initialize
member.summary: Uses the current buffer and envelope to force each of the contained layers to re-draw their content. This is useful after a zoom or size change.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.IMapFrame.Initialize(System.Collections.Generic.List{DotSpatial.Data.Extent})
member.summary: Instructs the map frame to draw content from the specified regions to the buffer..

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.IMapFrame.InvalidateLayers
member.summary: This will cause an invalidation for each layer. The actual rectangle to re-draw is not specified here, but rather this simply indicates that some re-calculation is necessary.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.IMapFrame.Pan(System.Drawing.Point)
member.summary: Pans the image for this map frame. Instead of drawing entirely new content, from all 5 zones, just the slivers of newly revealed area need to be re-drawn.
member.param: A Point showing the amount to shift in pixels

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.IMapFrame.ParentResize
member.summary: When the control is being resized, the view needs to change in order to preserve the aspect ratio, even though we want to use the exact same extents.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.IMapFrame.ParentToView(System.Drawing.Rectangle)
member.summary: Obtains a rectangle relative to the background image by comparing the current View rectangle with the parent control's size.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.IMapFrame.Print(System.Drawing.Graphics,System.Drawing.Rectangle)
member.summary: Instead of using the usual buffers, this bypasses any buffering and instructs the layers to draw directly to the specified target rectangle on the graphics object. This is useful for doing vector drawing on much larger pages. The result will be centered in the specified target rectangle bounds.
member.param: The target rectangle in the graphics units of the device

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.IMapFrame.Print(System.Drawing.Graphics,System.Drawing.Rectangle,DotSpatial.Data.Extent)
member.summary: Instead of using the usual buffers, this bypasses any buffering and instructs the layers to draw directly to the specified target rectangle on the graphics object. This is useful for doing vector drawing on much larger pages. The result will be centered in the specified target rectangle bounds.
member.param: Rectangle to draw the content to.
the extents to draw to the target rectangle

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.IMapFrame.ProjToBuffer(GeoAPI.Geometries.Coordinate)
member.summary: Converts a single geographic location into the equivalent point on the screen relative to the top left corner of the map.
member.returns: A Point with the new location.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.IMapFrame.ProjToBuffer(DotSpatial.Data.Extent)
member.summary: Converts a single geographic envelope into an equivalent Rectangle as it would be drawn on the screen.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.IMapFrame.ResetBuffer
member.summary: Re-creates the buffer based on the size of the control without changing the geographic extents. This is used after a resize operation.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.IMapFrame.ResetExtents
member.summary: This is not called during a resize, but rather after panning or zooming where the view is used as a guide to update the extents. This will also call ResetBuffer.

member.summary: Zooms in one notch, so that the scale becomes larger and the features become larger.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.IMapFrame.ZoomOut
member.summary: Zooms out one notch so that the scale becomes smaller and the features become smaller.

member.summary: Zooms to the next extent of the map frame

member.name: T:DotSpatial.Controls.MapFrame
member.summary: A MapFrame accomplishes two things. Firstly, it organizes the layers to be drawn, and establishes the geographic extents. Secondly, it hosts the back-buffer image that can be larger than the component that this map frame would normally be drawn to. When it receives instructions to paint itself, the client rectangle will automatically end up behaving like a clip rectangle.

member.summary: Forces this MapFrame to copy the buffers for its layers to the back-buffer.

member.summary: This will cause an invalidation for each layer. The actual rectangle to re-draw is not specified here, but rather this simply indicates that some re-calculation is necessary.

member.summary: Pans the image for this map frame. Instead of drawing entirely new content, from all 5 zones, just the slivers of newly revealed area need to be re-drawn.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.MapFrame.ParentResize

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.MapFrame.Print(System.Drawing.Graphics,System.Drawing.Rectangle)
member.summary: Instead of using the usual buffers, this bypasses any buffering and instructs the layers to draw directly to the specified target rectangle on the graphics object. This is useful for doing vector drawing on much larger pages. The result will be centered in the specified target rectangle bounds.

the extents to draw to the target rectangle

member.name: T:DotSpatial.Controls.SoutherlandHodgman
member.summary: Southerland Hodgman polygon clipper.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.SoutherlandHodgman.#ctor(System.Drawing.Rectangle)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.SoutherlandHodgman.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with a default clipping rectangle of -32000|64000 in both directions.

member.name: P:DotSpatial.Controls.SoutherlandHodgman.ClippingRectangle
member.summary: Gets or sets the clipping rectangle used in subsequent Clip calls.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.SoutherlandHodgman.Clip(System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Drawing.PointF})
member.summary: Calculates the Southerland-Hodgman clip using the actual drawing coordinates. This hopefully will be much faster than NTS which seems unncessarilly slow to calculate. http://www.codeguru.com/cpp/misc/misc/graphics/article.php/c8965
member.returns: A modified list of points that has been clipped to the drawing bounds.

member.name: M:DotSpatial.Controls.SoutherlandHodgman.Clip(System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Double[]})
member.summary: Calculates the Southerland-Hodgman clip using the actual drawing coordinates. This specific overload works with arrays of doubles instead of PointF structures. This hopefully will be much faster than NTS which seems unncessarilly slow to calculate. http://www.codeguru.com/cpp/misc/misc/graphics/article.php/c8965
member.param: The list of arrays of doubles where the X index is 0 and the Y index is 1.
member.returns: A modified list of points that has been clipped to the drawing bounds

member.summary: ParseCoordinates will understand lat-lon coordinates in a variety of formats and separate them into Degrees, Minutes, and Seconds. We could just accept a simple decimal value for the coordinates, but since users might be copying and pasting from a variety of sources it makes it user friendly to be able to accept a number of different formats.
member.param: An IList of doubles that is used to return the degrees, minutes and seconds.
The text that gets parsed to coordinates.
member.returns: Returns a bool indicating whether the given text could be parsed.
